dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, uh, earnings season is officially kicking off, and it's a big one, right? We're talking big banks and airlines leading the charge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, uh, earnings season is officially kicking off, and it's a big one, right? We're talking big banks and airlines leading the charge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Big banks and airlinestwo of the coronavirus pandemic's worst-hit industrieskick off earnings season on Tuesday, with JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Delta Air Lines all set to report before the opening bell.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, JPMorgan, Citigroup, Delta Air Lines, all reporting before the bell. And, um, not exactly rosy predictions, from what I'm seeing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, J P Morgan, Citigroup, Delta Air Lines, all reporting before the bell. And, um, not exactly rosy predictions, from what I'm seeing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Expect weak and uneven sales growth, and a collapse in profit margins, to characterize third-quarter results, Goldman Sachs said in a weekend note to clients...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Goldman Sachs is basically saying expect weak sales, profit margins just *poof*. But then, they also think the election results will impact stocks more than these actual earnings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Goldman Sachs is basically saying expect weak sales, profit margins just poof. But then, they also think the election results will impact stocks more than these actual earnings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Expect weak and uneven sales growth, and a collapse in profit margins, to characterize third-quarter results, Goldman Sachs said in a weekend note to clients, adding that it still expects election results will have more of an impact on stocks than earnings...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Which is, kinda, interesting. But they *do* emphasize the vaccine, right? Like, that's the real key to economic normalization.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, kinda, interesting. But they do emphasize the vaccine, right? Like, that's the real key to economic normalization.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...and that ultimately, vaccination is essential for the normalization of the economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And they're putting odds on it. Forty-eight percent chance for enough FDA-approved vaccine doses for 25 million Americans by Q2 or Q3 next year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And they're putting odds on it. Forty-eight percent chance for enough F D A approved vaccine doses for twenty five million Americans by Q two or Q three next year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Goldman believes theres a 48% chance that there will be enough doses of an FDA-approved coronavirus vaccine to treat 25 million Americans by the second or third quarters, the most likely time lines...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Or even 42% for Q1, which, you know, would be amazing. But Glenmede, they said 77% of lost economic activity has been regained. Sounds good, but still expecting just a small rebound in earnings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or even forty two percent for Q one, which, you know, would be amazing. But Glenmede, they said seventy seven percent of lost economic activity has been regained. Sounds good, but still expecting just a small rebound in earnings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Goldman believes theres a 48% chance that there will be enough doses of an FDA-approved coronavirus vaccine to treat 25 million Americans by the second or third quarters, the most likely time lines, followed closely by 42% odds that this will happen by the first quarter. Meanwhile, wealth management firm Glenmede said Monday that although it estimates 77% of economic activity lost due to social-distancing mandates has been regained, it only expects earnings will see a small rebound from an abysmal second quarter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and they don't see earnings hitting new highs until the second half of 2021, which, uh, coincidentally aligns with vaccine delivery estimates.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and they don't see earnings hitting new highs until the second half of twenty twenty one, which, uh, coincidentally aligns with vaccine delivery estimates.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Glenmede doesnt expect earnings will reach new highs until the second half of 2021, which the firm adds is not so coincidentally aligned with estimates for vaccine delivery.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: LPL Financial kind of echoed that, too. All those efficiencies from the recession, the winners doing well, and vaccine progress... suggests we might be, like, a year away from normalized earnings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: L P L Financial kind of echoed that, too. All those efficiencies from the recession, the winners doing well, and vaccine progress... suggests we might be, like, a year away from normalized earnings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a Monday note to clients, LPL Financial had similar hopes, saying, The combination of efficiencies gained during the recession, the strong performance of the winners and the tremendous progress in Covid-19 treatment and vaccine development, all suggest we may be only a year away from reaching normalized earnings...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's fascinating how different sectors are doing, though. Software, biotech, consumer staples like P&G? Totally thriving. P&G shares are, um, at an all-time high!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's fascinating how different sectors are doing, though. Software, biotech, consumer staples like P and G? Totally thriving. P and G shares are, um, at an all-time high!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The coronavirus pandemic has been a boon for stocks in software, biotech and consumer staples (think: Procter & Gamble, whose shares are at an all-time high and up 17% just this year)...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] While the other side of the coin, financials and energy? Just getting hammered. Energy down 36%, financials 16%. JPMorgan alone, like, 28% down this year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: While the other side of the coin, financials and energy? Just getting hammered. Energy down thirty six percent, financials sixteen percent. J P Morgan alone, like, twenty eight percent down this year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The worst-performing sectors are energy (down 36%) and financials (down 16%). JPMorgan, the nations biggest bank, led by Jamie Dimon, reports tomorrow and has seen shares plummet nearly 28% this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oof. So, overall, Goldman's estimating Q3 earnings per share for S&P 500 firms will drop by 21%. Better than Q2's 32% drop, but still a fall.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oof. So, overall, Goldman's estimating Q three earnings per share for S and P five hundred firms will drop by twenty one percent. Better than Q two's thirty two percent drop, but still a fall.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats how much Goldman said it expects third-quarter earnings per share will fall among S&P 500 firms, compared to a 32% drop in the second quarter and a 15% fall in the first.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. And, uh, Glenmede noted that the economy's recovery since spring has been "remarkable" in some ways.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. And, uh, Glenmede noted that the economy's recovery since spring has been remarkable in some ways.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In many respects, the economys recovery since this spring has been pretty remarkable. . . . Consensus estimates show an expectation that earnings reach new highs in the second half of 2021, perhaps not so coincidentally aligned with estimates for vaccine delivery, Glenmedes Jason Pride and Michael Reynolds said on Monday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It has been, but they also cautioned we're "not completely out of the woods yet." Those struggling pockets still need help, maybe another round of fiscal stimulus.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It has been, but they also cautioned we're not completely out of the woods yet. Those struggling pockets still need help, maybe another round of fiscal stimulus.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Consumers are driving the pandemic recovery, but the U.S. economy is not completely out of the woods yet. There are pockets of the economy that continue to struggle, and an additional round of fiscal stimulus could put the U.S. economy on a gentler and less painful path toward full recovery once a vaccine becomes widely available.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, a lot to watch this week then, especially with these big banks reporting, right? JPMorgan, Citi...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, a lot to watch this week then, especially with these big banks reporting, right? J P Morgan, Citi...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Among firms reporting Tuesday are Delta Air Lines, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, BlackRock and Johnson & Johnsonall before the opening bell.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. Signs of the economy mending from them could really, you know, boost bank stocks and the wider market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. Signs of the economy mending from them could really, you know, boost bank stocks and the wider market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Any signs on Tuesday from JPMorgan and Citi that the economy is on the mend will help bank stocks and the overall market, says Marc Chaikin, founder of Philadelphia-based quant investment research firm Chaikin Analytics.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I'm gonna be watching those numbers, uh, very closely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I'm gonna be watching those numbers, uh, very closely.
